title: Tbibek fi Jibek: Building Practical AI for Healthcare Access
author: Radiant Group
excerpt: How Radiant designed modular, deployable AI systems to improve healthcare orientation and accessibility in Tunisia.
content:
## Context
Most healthcare AI systems fail silently. Not because their models are inaccurate, but because their systems are not designed for real operational environments.

Healthcare settings are fragmented, data is imperfect, users are diverse, and decisions require justification. Tbibek fi Jibek was created to confront this reality directly.

## Problem Statement
Healthcare-oriented AI systems often assume ideal conditions: abundant data, stable infrastructure, and expert users. In practice, none of these assumptions hold.

The challenge is not building intelligence, but building *usable* intelligence.

## Why Common Approaches Fail
Monolithic architectures collapse multiple responsibilities into a single model. When they fail, it is impossible to diagnose why. They are difficult to evaluate, update, and deploy safely.

## Design Principles
- Modularity over monoliths
- Interpretability over raw accuracy
- Progressive deployment
- Explicit evaluation and failure analysis

## System Overview
Tbibek fi Jibek is a system-of-systems composed of independent AI modules: accessibility (TunSL), multimodal clinical assistance, nutrition guidance, dermatology triage, and wound analysis.

Each module exposes a clear interface and can operate independently or as part of a unified application.

## Technical Choices
We prioritized lightweight representations, task-specific models, and explicit orchestration logic over end-to-end intelligence.

## Data & Evaluation
Each module uses domain-appropriate metrics and independent evaluation pipelines. Failures are localized and analyzable.

## Limitations
The system is not a diagnostic tool. It provides orientation, assistance, and decision support, not clinical authority.

## Deployment Constraints
Design decisions were guided by hardware limitations, latency constraints, and accessibility requirements.

## Lessons Learned
Systems thinking matters more than model complexity. Modularity enables safety and iteration.

## Broader Implications
Healthcare AI must evolve from demos to dependable systems.

## Conclusion
Tbibek fi Jibek is not a product. It is a foundation for practical, accessible healthcare AI.
